column10: Richard B.|The Astrophysical Journal|585|2|1095|A coronal funnel model
column12: was tested against a calibrated spectroheliogram recorded in the 170-175 Å bandpass. This image was recorded on board a sounding-rocket experiment flown on 1994 November 3
column13: called the Multi-Spectral Solar Telescope Array II (MSSTA II). MSSTA
column14: a joint project of Stanford University

column17: is an observing platform composed of a set of normal-incidence
column18: multilayer-coated optics designed to obtain narrow-bandpass
column21: and soft X-ray wavelengths (44-1550 Å). Using full-disk images centered at 1550 Å (C IV) and 173 Å (Fe IX/X)
column23: which is based on coronal back-heating
column24: was tested against the data incorporating observed constraints on global coverage and measured flux. Found was a class of funnel models that could account for the quiescent
column25: globally diffuse and unresolved emission seen in the 171-175 Å bandpass
column26: where the funnels are assumed to be rooted in the C IV supergranular network. These models
column27: when incorporated with the CHIANTI spectral code
column28: suggest that this emission is mostly of upper transition region origin and primarily composed of Fe IX plasma. The funnels are found to have constrictions
column30: which is in good agreement with the observations. Further
column31: the fitted models simultaneously satisfy global areal constraints seen in both images; namely
column32: that a global network of funnels must cover ~70%-95% of the total solar surface area seen in the 171-175 Å image
column33: and <=45% of the disk area seen in the 1550 Å bandpass. These findings support the configuration of the EUV magnetic network as suggested by Reeves et al. and put forth in more detail by Gabriel. Furthermore
column34: the models are in good agreement with differential emission measure estimates made of the transition region by J. C. Raymond & J. G. Doyle for temperatures 250
